content.description:
30 Meters right of Lone Ranger, climb up an ice ramp for 20 meters, to the vertical headwall above. Crest the headwall and another 20 meters of rambling climbing is above to set a V thread of your choice.  It is the largest, furthest right main flow in Ranger Creek cirque, about an hour and a half walk from the car.

From the carpark, drop down the scree slope into the alders, and gravel stream beds.  Wander (hopefully following footprints in the snow for your first time) through the alders eventually popping out in a clearing with a straight shot view up into the cirque main drainage.  Just before the drainage cuts left around a corner, cut left up on to the scree slopes to avoid hiking through the drainage.  Follow your nose up and right to this route, either right away, or after climbing another first.  Screws. Vthread descend, bolts unknown.

The second pitch may be the crux. (We were the first ones on it one early season and my friend who had climbed this multiple times and free-soloed it before said it felt more like WI4+/5- that time.)

Screws. Rap off v-threads.

Found on the left side of the Ranger Creek gully, R&D is a single 50m pitch ice climb with a bolted anchor at the top. Rap the route with double ropes.

For the approach park on the south side of the Smith Dorien road next to the closed gate and bushwalk your way up the gully towards the obvious ice in the back. R&D is visible as a thinner line on the left, while "Lone Ranger" and the "Chalice and the Blade" are the more prominent ice lines in the middle of the cirque.

Youd expect to find early ice in the Canadian Rockies, where winter temperatures often drop below 30°F. For their first strikes, Alberta climbers usually head to Kananaskis area. K Country is the usual season opener around here, says Will Gadd, who lives in nearby Canmore. If you look at the ice conditions archives, its surprising how often October 14, or a few days either way, mark the start of the season.  
  
 Located along the Smith-Dorien/Spray Trail, a gravel road linking Canmore with Kananaskis Country, the Ranger Creek area, south of Burstall Pass, has high avalanche danger in midwinter, but is usually safe and easy to approach in late fall.  
  
 R&D (WI4+) is the classic, with a long, steep WI4+ column on the first pitch, followed by rambling easy ice to the top, about 45 minutes from the car. Farther up the same drainage, Lone Ranger (WI3+) and The Chalice and the Blade (WI5) offer additional steep challenges.
